title: 107_s2700
content: The "Social Security Attorney Fee Payment System Improvement Act of 2002" establishes a cap of $75 on attorney assessments under the Social Security Act. This amendment applies to fees for claimant representation certified or paid on or after 120 days from the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Act extends the attorney fee payment system to Title XVI claims. The "Social Security Attorney Fee Payment System Improvement Act of 2002" amends Section 1631(d)(2) of the Social Security Act by updating certain provisions related to attorney fees. This includes changes to subsections (a)(2)(B) and (a)(2)(D) and extends the attorney fee payment system to Title XVI claims. The "Social Security Attorney Fee Payment System Improvement Act of 2002" makes amendments to Section 1631(d)(2) of the Social Security Act, including changes to subsections (a)(2)(B) and (b)(1)(B)(i), extending the attorney fee payment system to Title XVI claims. The "Social Security Attorney Fee Payment System Improvement Act of 2002" includes amendments to Section 1631(d)(2) of the Social Security Act, extending the attorney fee payment system to Title XVI claims. This involves changes to subsections (a)(2)(B) and (b)(1)(B)(i), specifying the payment of attorney fees from past-due benefits, subject to certain conditions. The "Social Security Attorney Fee Payment System Improvement Act of 2002" includes amendments to Section 1631(d)(2) of the Social Security Act, extending the attorney fee payment system to Title XVI claims. This involves changes to subsections (a)(2)(B) and (b)(1)(B)(i), specifying the payment of attorney fees from past-due benefits, subject to certain conditions. The Commissioner imposes an assessment on attorneys receiving fees from claimants' past-due benefits, calculated based on the representative's fee amount before any reductions, with a maximum assessment of $75. The Commissioner imposes an assessment on attorneys receiving fees from claimants' past-due benefits, not exceeding 6.3 percent. The assessment can be collected by offsetting it from the fee owed to the attorney. Attorneys cannot seek reimbursement for the assessment from the claimant. Collected assessments are deposited in a separate Treasury fund and are only available for obligation as needed. The amendments authorize collected assessments to remain available for administrative expenses. The effective date applies to fees for representation of claimants certified under the Social Security Act.
